item.title: Exploring the magnetic phases in the one-band Hubbard model: Impact of long-range hopping
item.description:
Author(s): Sudip Mandal, Sandip Halder, and Kalpataru Pradhan

Correlated electron systems with competing interactions provide a valuable platform for examining exotic magnetic phases. Theoretical models often focus on nearest-neighbor interactions, although long-range interactions can have a considerable impact on the behavior of the system, creating distinct …


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 085150] Published Wed Aug 27, 2025

item.title: Multiple magnetic transitions, anomalous Hall effect, and tunable surface states in $\mathrm{Mn}{({\mathrm{Bi}}_{1−x}{\mathrm{Sb}}_{x})}_{4}{\mathrm{Te}}_{7}$
item.description:
Author(s): Chandan De, Keisuke Fukutani, Junho Seo, Roland Stania, Koichiro Yaji, Kenta Kuroda, Kenya Shimada, Jun Sung Kim, Han Woong Yeom, and Sang-Wook Cheong

Mn(Bi1−xSbx)4Te7 is a layered magnetic topological material that hosts multiple magnetic ground states and tunable surface Dirac states. This system is particularly suited for studying the interplay between magnetism and topology, relevant to quantum anomalous Hall phases. Here, the authors investigate the evolution of surface electronic structure using high-resolution angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) on high-quality single crystals. They find that Sb doping drives a transition from gapless to gapped Dirac surface states, revealing how subtle chemical tuning controls topological and magnetic properties in this material family.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 085151] Published Wed Aug 27, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Chandan De, Keisuke Fukutani, Junho Seo, Roland Stania, Koichiro Yaji, Kenta Kuroda, Kenya Shimada, Jun Sung Kim, Han Woong Yeom, and Sang-Wook Cheong

Mn(Bi1−xSbx)4Te7 is a layered magnetic topological material that hosts multiple magnetic ground states and tunable surface Dirac states. This system is particularly suited for studying the interplay between magnetism and topology, relevant to quantum anomalous Hall phases. Here, the authors investigate the evolution of surface electronic structure using high-resolution angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) on high-quality single crystals. They find that Sb doping drives a transition from gapless to gapped Dirac surface states, revealing how subtle chemical tuning controls topological and magnetic properties in this material family.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 085151] Published Wed Aug 27, 2025

item.title: Integrability of the Kondo model with time-dependent interaction strength
item.description:
Author(s): Parameshwar R. Pasnoori

In this Letter we consider the time-dependent Kondo model where a magnetic impurity interacts with the electrons through a time-dependent interaction strength $J(t)$. We develop an alternative framework based on the Bethe ansatz and construct an exact solution to the time-dependent Schrödinger equat…


[Phys. Rev. B 112, L060409] Published Tue Aug 26, 2025

item.description:

We describe the results of x-ray fluorescence holography (XFH) measurements of $1{T}^{′}\text{−}{\mathrm{TaTe}}_{2}$, in which Ta ribbon clusters that appear at high temperatures change to heptamers at low temperatures. It was previously thought that the ribbon cluster in the high-temperature phase …


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 064112] Published Mon Aug 25, 2025
item.content:encoded:

We describe the results of x-ray fluorescence holography (XFH) measurements of 1T′−TaTe2, in which Ta ribbon clusters that appear at high temperatures change to heptamers at low temperatures. It was previously thought that the ribbon cluster in the high-temperature phase was composed of multiple lin…


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 064112] Published Mon Aug 25, 2025

item.title: Pressure and strain effects on the ab initio $GW$ electronic structure of ${\mathrm{La}}_{3}{\mathrm{Ni}}_{2}{\mathrm{O}}_{7}$
item.description:
Author(s): Jean-Baptiste de Vaulx, Quintin N. Meier, Pierre Toulemonde, Andrés Cano, and Valerio Olevano

The bilayer compound La3Ni2O7 under high pressure has long held the superconducting Tc record among the nickelates, triggering a considerable amount of experimental and theoretical work to understand its main electronic properties. This work presents an ab initio analysis of these properties within the G0W0 approximation for different pressures and under epitaxial strain, showing features consistent with ARPES data as well as interesting effects. Among these, a strong renormalization of the rare-earth band and a slight deviation from conventional Fermi-liquid behavior stand out.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 085143] Published Mon Aug 25, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Jean-Baptiste de Vaulx, Quintin N. Meier, Pierre Toulemonde, Andrés Cano, and Valerio Olevano

The bilayer compound La3Ni2O7 under high pressure has long held the superconducting Tc record among the nickelates, triggering a considerable amount of experimental and theoretical work to understand its main electronic properties. This work presents an ab initio analysis of these properties within the G0W0 approximation for different pressures and under epitaxial strain, showing features consistent with ARPES data as well as interesting effects. Among these, a strong renormalization of the rare-earth band and a slight deviation from conventional Fermi-liquid behavior stand out.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 085143] Published Mon Aug 25, 2025
item.dc:title: Pressure and strain effects on the ab initio $GW$ electronic structure of ${\mathrm{La}}_{3}{\mathrm{Ni}}_{2}{\mathrm{O}}_{7}$

item.title: Many-body perturbation theory for moiré systems
item.description:
Author(s): Liangtao Peng, Giovanni Vignale, and Shaffique Adam

Moiré materials exhibit a rich spectrum of correlated phases, most notably superconductivity and insulating behavior driven by interactions. Existing theories often rely on mean-field approximations, which miss important correlation effects. Here, the authors build a many-body perturbation theory tailored to moiré systems, using Green’s functions to go beyond mean-field. Their approach captures symmetry-breaking states, finite-temperature transitions, and self-consistent corrections to electronic properties. This framework opens a new route to better understand how interactions shape the rich physics of moiré materials.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 075146] Published Fri Aug 22, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Liangtao Peng, Giovanni Vignale, and Shaffique Adam

Moiré materials exhibit a rich spectrum of correlated phases, most notably superconductivity and insulating behavior driven by interactions. Existing theories often rely on mean-field approximations, which miss important correlation effects. Here, the authors build a many-body perturbation theory tailored to moiré systems, using Green’s functions to go beyond mean-field. Their approach captures symmetry-breaking states, finite-temperature transitions, and self-consistent corrections to electronic properties. This framework opens a new route to better understand how interactions shape the rich physics of moiré materials.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 075146] Published Fri Aug 22, 2025
item.dc:title: Many-body perturbation theory for moiré systems
item.dc:creator: Liangtao Peng, Giovanni Vignale, and Shaffique Adam

item.title: Plasmonic interferences sampled by a diffraction grating generate moiré fringes
item.description:
Author(s): Marin Tharrault, Guillaume Boulliard, Emmanuel Lhuillier, and Aloyse Degiron

We report on the formation of moiré patterns when observing the diffraction of surface plasmons by periodic gratings of finite extent with an imaging spectrometer that maps the light emission as a function of the wavelength and the propagation distance. This phenomenon results from the formation of …

item.title: Negative currents in Fabry-Pérot cavities are caused by interfering paths
item.description:
Author(s): Mrinmoyee Saha, Luca Horray, Pedro Portugal, and Christian Flindt

The authors present here an analytic theory for the surprising prediction of negative currents in driven Fabry-Pérot cavities. They show that the negative currents arise from interference between electron paths making different numbers of round trips. The theory predicts how increasing temperature suppresses the effect, offering a clear test for upcoming experiments in ultraclean materials such as graphene.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, L081408] Published Thu Aug 21, 2025
item.content:encoded:
Author(s): Mrinmoyee Saha, Luca Horray, Pedro Portugal, and Christian Flindt

The authors present here an analytic theory for the surprising prediction of negative currents in driven Fabry-Pérot cavities. They show that the negative currents arise from interference between electron paths making different numbers of round trips. The theory predicts how increasing temperature suppresses the effect, offering a clear test for upcoming experiments in ultraclean materials such as graphene.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, L081408] Published Thu Aug 21, 2025

item.title: Entanglement in the pseudogap regime of cuprate superconductors
item.description:
Author(s): Frederic Bippus, Juraj Krsnik, Motoharu Kitatani, Luka Akšamović, Anna Kauch, Neven Barišić, and Karsten Held

We find a strongly enhanced entanglement within the pseudogap regime of the Hubbard model. This entanglement is estimated from the quantum Fisher information and, avoiding the ill-conditioned analytical continuation, the quantum variance. Both are lower bounds for the actual entanglement and can be …
